facts.text: Petition No. 62 of 1962 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: Petition No. 62 of 1962. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: The Jay Engineering Works Limited V. The Union of India (Writ Petition 64 of 1962) was heard along with this petition.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition 64 of 1962  The Jay Engineering, Works Limited V. The Union of India  was heard along with this petition. In that writ petition a further question arose as to the nature of the production bonus scheme in force in that companypany and parties have been given time to file additional. affidavits in that companynection.

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1 is a public limited company engaged in the manufacture of engineering goods, structural fabrication and rolling stock.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. 1  hereinafter referred to as the Company  is a public limited companypany engaged in the manifacture of engineering goods, structural fabrication and rolling stock, and the Act applies to the Company.

facts.text: The Employees Provident Funds Act, No. 19 of 1952 applies to the Company.

anchor.surface_text: and the Act applies to the Company. The Company has a production bonus scheme in force which provides for payment of production bonus over and above wages fixed by the major engineering award of 1958

facts.text: The Company has a production bonus scheme in force providing payment over and above wages fixed by the major engineering award of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Company has a production bonus scheme in force which provides for payment of production bonus over and above wages fixed by the major engineering award of 1958, published in the Calcutta gazette dated November 5, 1958, which governs 74 major engineering companycerns in that region including the Company

facts.text: Major engineering award of 1958 published in Calcutta gazette dated November 5, 1958, governs 74 major engineering concerns including the Company.

anchor.surface_text: major engineering award of 1958, published in the Calcutta gazette dated November 5, 1958, which governs 74 major engineering companycerns in that region including the Company That award is still in force and has fixed basic wages and dearness allowance on time rate basis for the entire major engineering industry.

facts.text: The award is still in force and has fixed basic wages and dearness allowance on time rate basis.

anchor.surface_text: That award is still in force and has fixed basic wages and dearness allowance on time rate basis for the entire major engineering industry. In addition to basic wages and dearness allowance payable under the award, the Company has two production bonus schemes one for the hourly rated workers and the other for the rest.

facts.text: The Company has two production bonus schemes: one for hourly rated workers and the other for the rest.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to basic wages and dearness allowance payable under the award, the Company has two production bonus schemes one for the hourly rated workers and the other for the rest.

facts.text: Production bonus begins to be paid when output reaches 5,000 tons per year; no production bonus when output is less than 5,000 tons per year.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to go into the details of the two schemes but the main feature of the two schemes is that production bonus begins to be paid on certain rates specified in the two schemes when the output reaches 5,000 tons per year and that numberproduction bonus is paid when the output is less than 5,000 tons per year.

facts.text: Scheme for hourly rated workers revised from January 1, 1962, applicable on quarterly basis; bonus begins at 1300 tons per quarter, none below.

anchor.surface_text: It maybe added that t,he scheme relating to the hourly rated workers has been revised from January 1, 1962 and the main feature of this revision is that the Scheme is number applicable to those workers on a quarterly basis. According to this revised scheme, production bonus begins when the output for the quarter reaches 1300 tons, and there is numberproduction bonus if the output is below 1300 tons.

facts.text: Negotiations are going on for revising the old scheme for other staff to bring it in line with the new scheme for hourly rated workers.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of other staff, the old scheme is still in force, though it is stated for the Company that negotiations are going on for revising the old scheme, presumably to bring it into line with the new scheme introduced for hourly rated workers since January 1, 1962.

facts.text: Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 framed in September 1952 and applicable to the Company.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence a Provident Fund Scheme was framed in September 1952 knows as the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952, and it is applicable to the companypany.

facts.text: Central Government directed on about March 7, 1962 that production bonus satisfies definition of basic wages under s.2(b), to recover PF contributions on it without delay, arrears from January 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that difficulties and doubts arose on the question whether production bonus companyld be taken into account in calculating the companytribution of 6-1/4 per centum under s. 6 of the Act, and the Central Government directed about the March 7, 1962 that the question whether production bonus should be liable to provident fund deduction under the Act had been reexamined by it and it had been decided that production bonus, payable as part of a companytract of employment either at a flat, rate or at a rate linked to the quantum of work turned out satisfied the definition of basic wages under s. 2  b  of the Act. The Company was further directed to effect recovery of provident fund companytributions on production bonus without any farther delay and arrear companytribution in this respect payable with effect from January 1, 1960, was also to be deposited in the statutory fund immediately.

facts.text: Present petition filed in April 1962 against the Central Government's decision communicated in March 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The present petition was thereafter filed in April 1962 and is directed against the decision of the Central Government which was duly companymunicated to the Company in March 1962.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 11, 1962 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. September 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-The short question raised in this writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is whether production bonus is included within the term basic wages as defined in s. 2 b  of the Employees Provident Funds Act, No. 19 of 1952

facts.text: Petitioner contends that bonus without qualification is excluded from basic wages in s.2(b), including production bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention of the Company is that bonus without any qualification has been expected from the terra ,basic wages in the definition in s. 2 b  of the Act. Therefore, all kinds of bonus whether it be profit bonus or production bonus or attendance bonus or festival bonus either as an implied companydition of service or as a customary payment, are excluded from basic wages.

facts.text: Respondents contend that production bonus is incentive wage, earned while on duty per contract, included in basic wages as all emoluments.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended for the respondents that wages are the price for labour and arise out of companytract, and the use of the term basic wages merely indicates that a certain part of the total wages is being separated for certain purposes only. Therefore production bonus being in the nature of incentive wage must be included in the definition of the term basic wages in s. 2 b

facts.text: Respondents contend that 'bonus' in s.2(b) exception refers only to profit bonus.

anchor.surface_text: It is further submitted that when the word bonus was used in el.  ii  of the exceptions to s. 2 b , it only referred to profit bonus, as it was well established before 1952 that the use of the word bonus without any qualification referred to profit bonus only in industrial adjudications.

facts.text: Court holds production bonus excluded from basic wages under s.2(b) as it is a kind of bonus.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that production bonus of this type is excluded from the definition of basic wages in P. 2  b  and therefore the decision of the Central Government, which was presumably under s. 19A of the Act, to remove the difficulty arising a out of giving effect to the provisions of the Act, by which such a bonus has been included in the definition of basic wages is incorrect.

facts.text: Court sets aside Central Government's decision communicated March 7, 1962 requiring PF contributions on production bonus.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the petition and hold that production bonus of the typical kind in force in the Company is excepted from the term basic wages and therefore the decision of the Central Government companymunicated to the Company on March 7, 1962, that provident fund companytributions must also be made on the production bonus earned by the employees in his Company, must be set aside.

facts.text: Production bonus scheme has base/standard of 5000 tons/year (1300/quarter for hourly), paid beyond that; minimum basic wages paid regardless.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme in force in the Company is a typical scheme of production bonus of this kind with a base or standard upto which basic wages as time wages are paid and thereafter extra payments are made for superior performance. This extra payment may be called incentive wage and is also called production bonus.

facts.text: Various kinds of bonuses (production, festival, customary, attendance, profit) were known and in force before 1952 Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed on behalf of the respondents that bonuses other than profit bonus were in force and well-known before the Act came to be passed in 1952. For example, the Coal Mines Provident Fund and Bonus Schemes Act, No. 46 of 1948, provided for payment of bonus depending on attendance of employees during any period. Besides the attendance bonus, four other kinds of bonus had been evolved under industrial law even before 1952
Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. B. Pai, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain for the petitioners.

if the word bonus therein excludes production bonus the provision would be unconstitutional as it would be hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution inasmuch as production bonus is not a general feature of all industrial concerns but has been introduced only in some.

anchor.surface_text: the term basic wages as defined in s. 2 b  of the Employees Provident Funds Act, No. 19 of 1952,  hereinafter referred to as the Act  Writ Petition 64 of 1962  The Jay Engineering, Works Limited V. The Union of India  was heard along with this petition.

Basic wages have been defined in s. 2 b  of the Act thus Basic wages means all emoluments which are earned by an employee while on duty or on leave with wages in accordance, with the terms of the contract of employment and which are paid or payable in cash to him, but does not include- the cash value of any food concession any dearness allowance  that is to say, all cash payments by whatever name called paid to an employee on account of a rise in the cost of living , house-rent allowance, overtime allowance bonus, commission or any other similar allowance payable to the employee in respect of his employment or of work done in such employment, any presents made by the employer

concepts.interpretation: Court interprets 'bonus' in exclusion clause (cl.ii) without qualification to include all kinds of bonus prevalent before 1952 (production, profit, attendance, festival, customary), excluding them from basic wages. Basis: payments not uniformly payable in all concerns or earned by all employees.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act provides for contribution by the employer and the employee to the provident fund and this contribution is 6- 1/4 per centum of the basic wages, dearness allowance end retaining allowance  if any  for the time being payable in the case of both.

concepts.interpretation: Contributions calculated on basic wages, dearness allowance, retaining allowance; excludes bonus as not part of basic wages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Word 'bonus' in cl.ii without qualification includes all kinds (production, attendance, festival, customary, profit) known pre-1952; exclusions based on uniformity - not payable in all concerns or earned by all employees.

holdings.text: the basis of inclusion in s. 6 and exclusion in cl. ii is that whatever is payable in all concerns and is earned by all permanent employees is included for the purpose of contribution under s. 6, but whatever is not payable by all concerns or may not be earned by all employees of a concern is excluded

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from structure of s.2(b) exceptions and s.6 inclusions (dearness/retaining allowances universal; house-rent/overtime/commission variable); ensures uniform PF incidence across concerns.

holdings.text: when the word bonus is used in cl. ii without any qualifying word, it should be interpreted to include all kinds of bonus which were known to industrial adjudication before 1952

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature aware of pre-1952 bonuses (production per Titaghur Paper Mills; festival per Ispahani; customary per Graham Trading; attendance per Coal Mines Act; profit per Millowners); unqualified 'bonus' covers all; profit bonus specified by year.

holdings.text: production bonus of the typical kind in force in the Company is excepted from the term basic wages and therefore the decision of the Central Government communicated to the Company on March 7, 1962... must be set aside
